"[3565-a polite and courteous man , who , noting clyde on the very first morning of his arrival here] But in the most gentle and solicitous tone , as [Clyde]197-clyde could hear and feel , even though [he]197-clyde stood blank and icy — afraid almost to move — or think . Yet in this mood — and because [he]197-clyde felt so truly done for , replying : " Yes , [I]197-clyde guess [I]197-clyde am . "[197-clyde] But once it was out , wondering why [he]197-clyde had said it ( so weak a confession ) and afterwards something in [the man]504-the man heartening [him]197-clyde , wishing that [he]197-clyde had not .

" [Your]197-clyde name 's [Griffiths]197-clyde , is n't it ? "[504-the man]

" Yes . "[197-clyde]

" Well , [my]197-clyde name 's [Nicholson]418-nicholson . Do n't be frightened . [You]197-clyde 'll get used to it . "[197-clyde] [He]197-clyde achieved a cheerful , if wan smile . But [his]197-clyde eyes — they did not seem like that — no smile there .

" [I]197-clyde do n't suppose [I]197-clyde 'm so scared either , "[197-clyde] replied [Clyde]197-clyde , trying to modify [his]197-clyde first , quick and unintended confession .

" Well , that 's good . Be game . [We]6233-we all have to be here — or [the whole place]6234-the whole place would go crazy . Better breathe a little . Or walk fast . It 'll do [you]197-clyde good . "[197-clyde]

[He]197-clyde moved away a few paces and began exercising [his]197-clyde arms while [Clyde]197-clyde stood there , saying — almost loudly — so shaken was [he]197-clyde still : " [We]6233-we all have to be or [the whole place]6234-the whole place would go crazy . "[197-clyde] That was true , as [he]197-clyde could see and feel after that first night . Crazy , indeed . Tortured to death , maybe , by being compelled to witness these terrible and completely destroying — and for each — impending tragedies . But how long would [he]197-clyde have to endure this ? How long would [he]197-clyde ?

In the course of a day or two , again [he]197-clyde found [this death house]3568-this death house was not quite like that either — not all terror — on the surface at least . It was in reality — and in spite of impending death in every instance , [a place of taunt and jibe and jest]3569-a place of taunt and jibe and jest — even games , athletics , the stage — all forms of human contest of skill — or the arguments on every conceivable topic from death and [women]2180-women to lack of it , as far at least as the general low intelligence of [the group]1514-the group permitted .

For the most part , as soon as breakfast was over — among [those who were not called upon to join the first group for exercise]3572-those who were not called upon to join the first group for exercise , there were checkers or cards , two games that were played — not with a single set of checkers or a deck of cards between groups released from [[their]1514-the group cells]3387-their cells , but by one of [the ever present keepers]3574-the ever present keepers providing [two challenging prisoners ( if it were checkers]3575-two challenging prisoners ( if it were checkers ) with one checker - board but no checkers . [They]3575-two challenging prisoners ( if it were checkers were not needed . Thereafter the opening move was called by [one]955-one . " [I]955-one move from G 2 to E 1"—each[955-one] square being numbered — each side lettered . The moves checked with a pencil .

Thereafter [the second party]3577-the second party — having recorded this move on [his]3577-the second party own board and having studied the effect of it on [his]3577-the second party own general position , would call : " [I]3577-the second party move from E 7 to F 5 . "[3577-the second party] If more of [those present decided to join in this]3578-those present decided to join in this — either on one side or the other , additional boards and pencils were passed to each signifying [his]3577-the second party desire . Then [Shorty Bristol]419-shorty bristol , desiring to aid " [Dutch "[419-shorty bristol] Swighort]420-dutch " swighort , [three cells]3579-three cells down , might call : " [I]3577-the second party would n't do that , [Dutch]420-dutch " swighort . Wait a minute , there 's a better move than that . "[3577-the second party] And so on with taunts , oaths , laughter , arguments , according to the varying fortunes and difficulties of the game . And so , too , with cards . These were played with [each man]3580-each man locked in [[his]3577-the second party cell]1588-his cell , yet quite as successfully .

But [Clyde]197-clyde did not care for cards — or for these jibing and coarse hours of conversation . There was for [him]197-clyde — and with the exception of the speech of one — [Nicholson]418-nicholson — alone , too much ribald and even brutal talk which [he]197-clyde could not appreciate . But [he]197-clyde was drawn to [Nicholson]418-nicholson . [He]197-clyde was beginning to think after a time — a few days — that [this lawyer]3582-this lawyer — [his]197-clyde presence and companionship during the exercise hour — whenever [they]3583-they chanced to be in the same set — could help [him]197-clyde to endure this . [He]197-clyde was [the most intelligent and respectable man]3584-the most intelligent and respectable man [here]4244-here . [The others]903-the others were all so different — taciturn at times — and for the most part so sinister , crude or remote .

But then and that not more than a week after [his]197-clyde coming [here]4244-here — and when , because of [his]197-clyde interest in [Nicholson]418-nicholson , [he]197-clyde was beginning to feel slightly sustained at least — the execution of [Pasquale Cutrone]421-pasquale , of [Brooklyn]154-brooklyn , [an Italian]3588-an italian , convicted of the slaying of [[his]421-pasquale brother]2212-his brother for attempting to seduce [[his]421-pasquale wife]494-his wife . [He]421-pasquale had [one of [the cells nearest [the transverse passage]3593-the transverse passage]3592-the cells nearest the transverse passage]3591-one of the cells nearest the transverse passage , so [Clyde]197-clyde learned after arriving , and had in part lost [his]197-clyde mind from worrying . At any rate [he]197-clyde was invariably left in [[his]197-clyde cell]1588-his cell when [the others]903-the others — in groups of six — were taken for exercise . But the horror of [his]197-clyde emaciated face , as [Clyde]197-clyde passed and occasionally looked in — a face divided into three grim panels by two gutters or prison lines of misery that led from the eyes to the corners of the mouth .

Beginning with [his]197-clyde , [Clyde]197-clyde 's arrival , as [he]197-clyde learned , [Pasquale]421-pasquale had begun to pray night and day . For already , before that , [he]421-pasquale had been notified of the approximate date of [his]421-pasquale death which was to be within the week . And after that [he]197-clyde was given to crawling up and down [[his]197-clyde cell]1588-his cell on [his]197-clyde hands and knees , kissing the floor , licking the feet of [a brass Christ]3597-a brass christ on a cross that had been given [him]197-clyde . Also [he]197-clyde was repeatedly visited by [an Italian brother and sister fresh from [Italy]163-italy and for whose benefit at certain hours , [he]197-clyde was removed to [the old death house]3353-the old death house]3598-an italian brother and sister fresh from italy and for whose benefit at certain hours , he was removed to the old death house . But as all now whispered , [Pasquale]421-pasquale was mentally beyond any help that might lie in [brothers]2308-brothers or [sisters]2192-sisters .

All night long and all day long , when [they]3602-they were not present , [he]421-pasquale did this crawling to and fro and praying , and [those who were awake and trying to read to pass the time]3603-those who were awake and trying to read to pass the time , were compelled to listen to [his]421-pasquale mumbled prayers , the click of the beads of a rosary on which [he]421-pasquale was numbering numberless [Our Fathers]3604-our fathers and [Hail Marys]422-hail marys .

And though there were voices which occasionally said : " Oh , for [Christ]412-christ 's sake — if [he]421-pasquale would only sleep a little"—still[421-pasquale] on , on . And the tap of [his]421-pasquale forehead on the floor — in prayer , until at last the fatal day preceding the one on which [he]421-pasquale was to die , when [Pasquale]421-pasquale was taken from [[his]421-pasquale cell]1588-his cell here and escorted to another in [the old death house]3353-the old death house beyond and where , before the following morning , as [Clyde]197-clyde later learned , last farewells , if any , were to be said . Also [he]421-pasquale was to be allowed a few hours in which to prepare [his]421-pasquale soul for [[his]421-pasquale maker]3607-his maker .

But throughout that night what a strange condition was this that settled upon [all who were of [this fatal room]3609-this fatal room]3608-all who were of this fatal room . [Few]3610-few ate any supper as the departing trays showed . There was silence — and after that mumbled prayers on the part of [some]3611-some — not so greatly removed by time from [Pasquale]421-pasquale 's fate , as [they]3611-some knew . [One Italian]3612-one italian , sentenced for the murder of [a bank watchman]3613-a bank watchman , became hysterical , screamed , dashed the chair and table of [[his]3612-one italian cell]1588-his cell against the bars of [his]3612-one italian door , tore the sheets of [his]3612-one italian bed to shreds and even sought to strangle [himself]3612-one italian before eventually [he]3612-one italian was overpowered and removed to [a cell in a different part of [the building]2984-the building]3615-a cell in a different part of the building to be observed as to [his]3612-one italian sanity .

As for [the others]903-the others , throughout this excitement , one could hear [them]903-the others walking and mumbling or calling to [the guards]3618-the guards to do something . And as for [Clyde]197-clyde , never having experienced or imagined such a scene , [he]197-clyde was literally shivering with fear and horror . All through the last night of [this man]749-this man 's life [he]197-clyde lay on [his]197-clyde pallet , chasing phantoms . So this was what death was like here ; [men]2208-men cried , prayed , [they]2208-men lost [their]2208-men minds — yet the deadly process was in no way halted , for all [their]2208-men terror . Instead , at ten o'clock and in order to quiet [all those who were left]3621-all those who were left , a cold lunch was brought in and offered — but with none eating save [the Chinaman]3622-the chinaman over the way .

And then at four the following morning — [the keepers in charge of the deadly work]3623-the keepers in charge of the deadly work coming silently along [the main passage]3624-the main passage and drawing the heavy green curtains with which [the cells]3307-the cells were equipped so that [none]3626-none might see the fatal procession which was yet to return along [the transverse passage]3593-the transverse passage from [the old death house]3353-the old death house to [the execution room]3629-the execution room . And yet with [Clyde]197-clyde and [all the others]3015-all the others waking and sitting up at the sound .

It was here , the execution ! The hour of death was at hand . This was the signal . In [[their]2208-men separate cells]3631-their separate cells , many of [those who through fear or contrition , or because of innate religious convictions , had been recalled to some form of shielding or comforting faith]3632-those who through fear or contrition , or because of innate religious convictions , had been recalled to some form of shielding or comforting faith , were upon [their]2208-men knees praying . Among [the rest]3633-the rest were others who merely walked or muttered . And still [others who screamed from time to time in an incontrollable fever of terror]3634-others who screamed from time to time in an incontrollable fever of terror .

As for [Clyde]197-clyde [he]197-clyde was numb and dumb . Almost thoughtless . [They]3635-they were going to kill [that man in [that other room]3336-that other room in there]3636-that man in that other room in there . That chair — [that chair that [he]197-clyde had so greatly feared this long while was in there]3638-that chair that he had so greatly feared this long while was in there — was so close now . Yet [his]197-clyde time as [Jephson]320-jephson and [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother had told [him]197-clyde was so long and distant as yet — if ever — ever it was to be — if ever — ever —

But now other sounds . Certain walkings to and fro . A cell door clanking somewhere . Then plainly the door leading from [the old death house]3353-the old death house into [this room]1131-this room opening — for there was a voice — several voices indistinct as yet . Then another voice a little clearer as if [some one praying]3642-some one praying . That tell - tale shuffling of feet as a procession moved across and through [that passage]3643-that passage . " [Lord]6236-lord have mercy . [Christ]412-christ have mercy . "[3642-some one praying]

" [Mary]423-mary , [Mother of Grace]6237-mother of grace , [Mary]423-mary , [Mother of Mercy]6238-mother of mercy , [St. Michael]424-st. michael , pray for [me]3644-the priest ; [[my]3644-the priest good [Angel]425-angel]6239-my good angel , pray for [me]3644-the priest . "[3644-the priest]

" [Holy Mary]423-mary , pray for [me]3642-some one praying ; [St. Joseph]426-st. joseph , pray for [me]3642-some one praying . It was the voice of [the priest]3644-the priest accompanying [the doomed man]3645-the doomed man and reciting a litany . Yet [he]3645-the doomed man was no longer in [his]3645-the doomed man right mind [they]3646-they said . And yet was not that [his]3645-the doomed man voice mumbling too ? It was . [Clyde]197-clyde could tell . [He]197-clyde had heard it too much recently . And now that other door would be opened . " Good - by , [Cutrone]421-pasquale ! "[3646-they] It was a hoarse , shaky voice from [some near - by cell]3648-some near - by cell — [Clyde]197-clyde could not tell which . " Go to a better world than this . "[197-clyde] And then other voices : " Goodby , [Cutrone]421-pasquale . God keep [you]421-pasquale — even though [you]421-pasquale ca n't talk English . "[197-clyde]

The procession had passed . That door was shut . [He]3645-the doomed man was in [there]650-there now . [They]3646-they were strapping [him]3645-the doomed man in , no doubt . Asking [him]3645-the doomed man what more [he]3645-the doomed man had to say — [he]3650-he who was no longer quite right in [his]3645-the doomed man mind . Now the straps must be fastened on , surely . The cap pulled down . In a moment , a moment , surely —

And then , although [Clyde]197-clyde did not know or notice at the moment — a sudden dimming of the lights in [this room]1131-this room — as well as over [the prison]3012-the prison — an idiotic or thoughtless result of having one electric system to supply the death voltage and the incandescence of this and [all other rooms]3653-all other rooms . And instantly a voice calling :

" There [she]6242-she goes . That 's one . Well , it 's all over with [him]3645-the doomed man . "[197-clyde]

And a second voice : " Yes , [he]3645-the doomed man 's topped off , [poor devil]6243-poor devil . "[197-clyde]

And then after the lapse of a minute perhaps , a second dimming lasting for thirty seconds — and finally a third dimming .

" There — sure — that 's the end now . "[197-clyde]

" Yes . [He]3645-the doomed man knows what 's on the other side now . "[197-clyde]

Thereafter silence — a deadly hush with later some murmured prayers here and there . But with [Clyde]197-clyde cold and with a kind of shaking ague . [He]3645-the doomed man dared not think — let alone cry . So that 's how it was . [They]3646-they drew the curtains . And then — and then . [He]3645-the doomed man was gone now . Those three dimmings of the lights . Sure , those were the flashes . And after all those nights at prayer . Those moanings ! Those beatings of [his]3645-the doomed man head ! And only a minute ago [he]3645-the doomed man had been alive — walking by [there]650-there . But now dead . And some day [he]3645-the doomed man — [he!—how]3655-he!—how could [he]3645-the doomed man be sure that [he]3645-the doomed man would not ? How could [he]3645-the doomed man ?

[He]3645-the doomed man shook and shook , lying on [his]3645-the doomed man couch , face down . [The keepers]3656-the keepers came and ran up the curtains — as sure and secure in [their]3656-the keepers lives apparently as though there was no death in [the world]1694-the world . And afterwards [he]3645-the doomed man could hear [them]3656-the keepers talking — not to [him]3645-the doomed man so much — [he]3645-the doomed man had proved too reticent thus far — but to [some of [the others]903-the others]3658-some of the others .

[Poor Pasquale]428-poor pasquale . This whole business of the death penalty was all wrong . [The warden]3282-the warden thought so . So did [they]3656-the keepers . [He]3282-the warden was working to have it abolished .

But [that man]2466-that man ! [His]2466-that man prayers ! And now [he]2466-that man was gone . [[His]2466-that man cell over there]3662-his cell over there was empty and [another man]3663-another man would be put in it — to go too , later . Some one — many — like [Cutrone]421-pasquale , like [himself]3645-the doomed man — had been in this one — on [this pallet]3664-this pallet . [He]3645-the doomed man sat up — moved to the chair . But [he]3645-the doomed man — [they]3656-the keepers — had sat on that — too . [He]3645-the doomed man stood up — only to sink down on the pallet again . " [God]246-god ! [God]246-god ! [God]246-god ! [God]246-god ! "[3645-the doomed man] [he]3645-the doomed man now exclaimed to [himself]3645-the doomed man — but not aloud — and yet not unlike [that other man who had so terrorized [him]3645-the doomed man on the night of [his]3645-the doomed man arrival here and who was still [here]4244-here]3665-that other man who had so terrorized him on the night of his arrival here and who was still here . But [he]3645-the doomed man would go too . And [all of [these others]1155-these others]3667-all of these others — and [himself]3645-the doomed man maybe — unless — unless .

[He]3645-the doomed man had seen [[his]3645-the doomed man first man]3669-his first man die .

In the meantime , however , [Asa]335-mrs. griffiths 's condition had remained serious , and it was four entire months before it was possible for [him]3645-the doomed man to sit up again or for [Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths to dream of resuming [her]335-mrs. griffiths lecturing scheme . But by that time , public interest in [her]335-mrs. griffiths and [[her]335-mrs. griffiths son]2096-her son 's fate was considerably reduced . [No Denver paper]96-denver was interested to finance [her]335-mrs. griffiths return for anything [she]335-mrs. griffiths could do for [them]3671-them . And as for [the public in the vicinity of the crime]3672-the public in the vicinity of the crime , it remembered [Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths and [[her]335-mrs. griffiths son]2096-her son most clearly , and in so far as [she]335-mrs. griffiths was concerned , sympathetically — but only , on the other hand , to think of [him]3645-the doomed man as one who probably was guilty and in that case , being properly punished for [his]3645-the doomed man crime — that it would be as well if an appeal were not taken — or — if it were — that it be refused . [These guilty criminals]3674-these guilty criminals with [their]3674-these guilty criminals interminable appeals !

And with [Clyde]197-clyde where [he]197-clyde was , more and more executions — although as [he]197-clyde found — and to [his]197-clyde invariable horror , [no one]4176-no one ever became used to such things there ; [farmhand Mowrer]417-thomas mowrer for the slaying of [[his]417-thomas mowrer former employer]3676-his former employer ; [officer Riordan]429-officer riordan for the slaying of [[his]429-officer riordan wife]494-his wife — and [a fine upstanding officer]3678-a fine upstanding officer too but a minute before [his]429-officer riordan death ; and afterwards , within the month , the going of [the Chinaman]3622-the chinaman , who seemed , for some reason , to endure a long time ( and without a word in parting to [any one]4181-any one — although it was well known that [he]3622-the chinaman spoke a few words of English ) . And after [him]3622-the chinaman [Larry Donahue]416-big larry donahue , [the overseas soldier]3681-the overseas soldier — with a grand call — just before the door closed behind : " [Good - by boys]6244-good - by boys . Good luck . "[416-big larry donahue]

And after [him]416-big larry donahue again — but , oh — that was so hard ; so much closer to [Clyde]197-clyde — so depleting to [his]197-clyde strength to think of bearing this deadly life here without — [Miller Nicholson]418-nicholson — no less . For after five months in which [they]3682-they had been able to walk and talk and call to [each other]871-each other from time to time from [[their]3682-they cells]3387-their cells and [Nicholson]418-nicholson had begun to advise [him]418-nicholson as to books to read — as well as one important point in connection with [his]418-nicholson own case — on appeal — or in the event of any second trial , [i.e.]3685-i.e. ,—that the admission of [Roberta]195-roberta 's letters as evidence , as [they]3682-they stood , at least , be desperately fought on the ground that the emotional force of them was detrimental in the case of [any jury]4770-any jury anywhere , to a calm unbiased consideration of the material facts presented by [them]3682-they — and that instead of the letters being admitted as they stood they should be digested for the facts alone and that digest — and that only offered to [the jury]1953-the jury . " If [[your]197-clyde lawyers]5760-your lawyers can get [the Court of Appeals]164-the court of appeals to agree to the soundness of that [you]197-clyde will win [your]197-clyde case sure . "[197-clyde]

And [Clyde]197-clyde at once , after inducing a personal visit on the part of [Jephson]320-jephson , laying this suggestion before [him]320-jephson and hearing [him]320-jephson say that it was sound and that [he]320-jephson and [Belknap]324-belknap would assuredly incorporate it in [their]3688-their appeal .

Yet not so long after that [the guard]3422-the guard , after locking [his]320-jephson door on returning from [the courtyard]3690-the courtyard whispered , with a nod in the direction of [[Nicholson]418-nicholson 's cell]3691-nicholson 's cell , " [His]3693-another man who had just been brought in next . Did [he]3693-another man who had just been brought in tell [you]197-clyde ? Within three days . "[3422-the guard]

And at once [Clyde]197-clyde shriveling — the news playing upon [him]197-clyde as an icy and congealing breath . For [he]197-clyde had just come from [the courtyard]3690-the courtyard with [him]197-clyde where [they]3688-their had walked and talked of [another man who had just been brought in]3693-another man who had just been brought in — [a Hungarian of [Utica]30-utica who was convicted of burning [[his]3693-another man who had just been brought in paramour]3695-his paramour — in a furnace — then confessing it — [a huge , rough , dark , ignorant man with a face like a gargoyle]3696-a huge , rough , dark , ignorant man with a face like a gargoyle . And [Nicholson]418-nicholson saying [he]418-nicholson was more animal than [man]585-man , [he]418-nicholson was sure]3694-a hungarian of utica who was convicted of burning his paramour — in a furnace — then confessing it — a huge , rough , dark , ignorant man with a face like a gargoyle . and nicholson saying he was more animal than man , he was sure . Yet no word about [himself]418-nicholson . And in three days ! And [he]418-nicholson could walk and talk as though there was nothing to happen , although , according to [the guard]3422-the guard , [he]418-nicholson had been notified the night before .

And the next day the same — walking and talking as though nothing had happened — looking up at the sky and breathing the air . Yet [Clyde]197-clyde , [[his]418-nicholson companion]3699-his companion , too sick and feverish — too awed and terrified from merely thinking on it all night to be able to say much of anything as [he]418-nicholson walked but thinking : " And [he]418-nicholson can walk [here]4244-here . And be so calm . What sort of [a man]4220-a man is this ? "[197-clyde] and feeling enormously overawed and weakened .

The following morning [Nicholson]418-nicholson did not appear — but remained in [[his]418-nicholson cell]1588-his cell destroying many letters [he]418-nicholson had received from many places . And near noon , calling to [Clyde]197-clyde who was [two cells]3701-two cells removed from [him]418-nicholson on the other side : " [I]197-clyde 'm sending [you]418-nicholson something to remember [me]197-clyde by . "[197-clyde] But not a word as to [his]418-nicholson going .

And then [the guard]3422-the guard bringing two books — [Robinson Crusoe]430-robinson crusoe and the Arabian Nights . That night [Nicholson]418-nicholson 's removal from [[his]418-nicholson cell]1588-his cell — and the next morning before dawn the curtains ; the same procession passing through , which was by now an old story to [Clyde]197-clyde . But somehow this was so different — so intimate — so cruel . And as [he]418-nicholson passed , calling : " [God]246-god bless [you]1155-these others all . [I]418-nicholson hope [you]1155-these others have good luck and get out . "[418-nicholson] And then that terrible stillness that followed the passing of [each man]3580-each man .

And [Clyde]197-clyde thereafter — lonely — terribly so . Now there was [no one here]3705-no one here — [no one]4176-no one — in whom [he]197-clyde was interested . [He]197-clyde could only sit and read — and think — or pretend to be interested in what [these others]1155-these others said , for [he]197-clyde could not really be interested in what [they]1155-these others said . [His]197-clyde was a mind that , freed from the miseries that had now befallen [him]197-clyde , was naturally more drawn to romance than to reality . Where [he]197-clyde read at all [he]197-clyde preferred the light , romantic novel that pictured some such world as [he]197-clyde would have liked to share , to anything that even approximated the hard reality of [the world]1694-the world without , let alone this . Now what was going to become of [him]197-clyde eventually ? So alone was [he]197-clyde ! Only letters from [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother , [brother]4558-brother and [sisters]2192-sisters . And [Asa]335-mrs. griffiths getting no better , and [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother not able to return as yet — things were so difficult there in [Denver]96-denver . [She]688-his mother was seeking [a religious school in which to teach somewhere — while nursing [Asa]335-mrs. griffiths]3713-a religious school in which to teach somewhere — while nursing asa . But [she]688-his mother was asking [the Rev. [He]197-clyde was so spiritual and so kindly . And [she]688-his mother was sure , if [he]197-clyde would but come , that [Clyde]197-clyde would find [him]197-clyde a helpful and a strong support in these , [his]197-clyde dark and weary hours when [she]688-his mother could no longer be with [him]197-clyde [herself]688-his mother .

For while [Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths was first canvassing [the churches and ministers of [this section]3716-this section for aid for [[her]335-mrs. griffiths son]2096-her son]3715-the churches and ministers of this section for aid for her son , and getting very little from any quarter , [she]688-his mother had met [the Rev. Duncan McMillan]431-mcmillan in [Syracuse]119-syracuse , where [he]431-mcmillan was conducting [an independent , non - sectarian church]3718-an independent , non - sectarian church . [He]197-clyde was a young , and like [herself]688-his mother or [Asa]335-mrs. griffiths , [unordained minister or [evangelist of , however , far stronger and more effective temperament religiously]3720-evangelist of , however , far stronger and more effective temperament religiously]3719-unordained minister or evangelist of , however , far stronger and more effective temperament religiously . At the time [Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths appeared on the scene , [he]197-clyde had already read much concerning [Clyde]197-clyde and [Roberta]195-roberta — and was fairly well satisfied that , by the verdict arrived at , justice had probably been done . However , because of [her]335-mrs. griffiths great sorrow and troubled search for aid [he]197-clyde was greatly moved .

[He]197-clyde , [himself]197-clyde , was [a devoted son]3721-a devoted son . And possessing a highly poetic and emotional though so far repressed or sublimated sex nature , [he]197-clyde was one who , out of many in [this northern region]3722-this northern region , had been touched and stirred by the crime of which [Clyde]197-clyde was presumed to be guilty . Those highly emotional and tortured letters of [Roberta]195-roberta 's ! [Her]195-roberta seemingly sad life at [Lycurgus]33-lycurgus and [Biltz]14-biltz ! How often [he]197-clyde had thought of those before ever [he]197-clyde had encountered [Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths . The simple and worthy virtues which [Roberta]195-roberta and [[her]195-roberta family]1718-her family had seemingly represented in [that romantic , pretty country world from which [they]3725-they had derived]3724-that romantic , pretty country world from which they had derived . Unquestionably [Clyde]197-clyde was guilty . And yet here , suddenly , [Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths , very lorn and miserable and maintaining [[her]335-mrs. griffiths son]2096-her son 's innocence . At the same time there was [Clyde]197-clyde in [[his]197-clyde cell]1588-his cell doomed to die . Was it possible that by any strange freak or circumstance — a legal mistake had been made and [Clyde]197-clyde was not as guilty as [he]197-clyde appeared ?

The temperament of [McMillan]431-mcmillan was exceptional — tense , exotic . A present hour [St. Bernard]432-st. bernard , [Savonarola]165-savonarola , [St. Simeon]433-st. simeon , [Peter the Hermit]434-peter the hermit . Thinking of life , thought , all forms and social structures as the word , the expression , the breath of [God]246-god . No less . " [He]436-st. john that is not with [me]436-st. john is against [me]436-st. john ; and [he]436-st. john that gathereth not with [me]436-st. john , scattereth . "[436-st. john] [A strange , strong , tense , confused , merciful and too]3730-a strange , strong , tense , confused , merciful and too , after [his]436-st. john fashion beautiful soul ; sorrowing with misery yearning toward an impossible justice .

[Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths in [her]335-mrs. griffiths talks with [him]436-st. john had maintained that [he]436-st. john was to remember that [Roberta]195-roberta was not wholly guiltless . Had [she]335-mrs. griffiths not sinned with [[her]335-mrs. griffiths son]2096-her son ? And how was [he]436-st. john to exculpate [her]335-mrs. griffiths entirely ? A great legal mistake . [[Her]335-mrs. griffiths son]2096-her son was being most unjustly executed — and by the pitiful but none - the - less romantic and poetic letters of [this girl]818-this girl which should never have been poured forth upon [a jury of [men at all]3735-men at all]3734-a jury of men at all . [They]3736-they were , as [she]335-mrs. griffiths now maintained , incapable of judging justly or fairly where anything sad in connection with [a romantic and pretty girl]3737-a romantic and pretty girl was concerned . [She]335-mrs. griffiths had found that to be true in [her]335-mrs. griffiths mission work .

And this idea now appealed to [the Rev. Duncan]431-mcmillan as important and very likely true . And perhaps , as [she]335-mrs. griffiths now contended , if only [some powerful and righteous emissary of God]3738-some powerful and righteous emissary of god would visit [Clyde]197-clyde and through the force of [his]197-clyde faith and [God]246-god 's word make [him]197-clyde see — which [she]335-mrs. griffiths was sure [he]197-clyde did not yet , and which [she]335-mrs. griffiths in [her]335-mrs. griffiths troubled state , and because [she]335-mrs. griffiths was [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother , could not make [him,—the]3740-him,—the blackness and terror of [his]197-clyde sin with [Roberta]195-roberta as it related to [his]197-clyde immortal soul here and hereafter,—then in gratitude to , reverence and faith in [God]246-god , would be washed away , all [his]197-clyde iniquity , would it not ? For irrespective of whether [he]197-clyde had committed the crime now charged against [him]197-clyde or not — and [she]335-mrs. griffiths was convinced that [he]197-clyde had not — was [he]197-clyde not , nevertheless , in the shadow of the electric chair — in danger at any time through death ( even before a decision should be reached ) of being called before [[his]197-clyde maker]3607-his maker — and with the deadly sin of adultery , to say nothing of all [his]197-clyde lies and false conduct , not only in connection with [Roberta]195-roberta but [that other girl there in [Lycurgus]33-lycurgus]3742-that other girl there in lycurgus , upon [him]197-clyde ? And after a first and later a second pleading letter from [Mrs. Griffiths]335-mrs. griffiths , in which , after [she]335-mrs. griffiths had arrived at [Denver]96-denver , [she]335-mrs. griffiths set forth [Clyde]197-clyde 's loneliness and need of counsel and aid , [the Rev. Duncan]431-mcmillan setting forth for [Auburn]159-auburn . And then [McMillan]431-mcmillan outlining [his]197-clyde tall , thin figure against the bars and without introduction of any kind , beginning , [his]197-clyde head bowed in prayer .

[McMillan]431-mcmillan paused — but only after [he]431-mcmillan had intoned , and in a most sonorous and really beautiful voice the entire 51st Psalm . " [I]431-mcmillan bring [you]197-clyde , [Clyde]197-clyde , the mercy and the salvation of [[your]197-clyde God]5738-your god . [McMillan]431-mcmillan paused and stared at [Clyde]197-clyde tenderly . A warm , youthful , half smile , half romantic , played about [his]431-mcmillan lips . Another religionist , of course . " [Duncan McMillan]431-mcmillan is [my]749-this man name , "[749-this man] [he]749-this man said , " and [I]749-this man come from the work of [the Lord]3114-the lord in [Syracuse]119-syracuse . And [I]749-this man know why [you]197-clyde are here . But it is to bring [you]197-clyde spiritual joy and gladness that [I]749-this man am here . "[749-this man]

And [he]749-this man suddenly quoted from Psalms 13:2 .

" [Clyde]197-clyde , those are all words addressed to [you]197-clyde . [I]749-this man am but the mouthpiece for these words spoken direct to [you]197-clyde . Take counsel with [your]197-clyde own heart . Turn from the shadow to the light . " Do [you]197-clyde think there is [no God]6261-no god — and that [He]6255-the lord will not answer [you]197-clyde ? Pray . "[3753-me] [He]3753-me paused , serious and conclusive in [his]3753-me tone — because up to this time , [Clyde]197-clyde had looked more curious and astonished than anything else .

At the same time because of [Clyde]197-clyde 's extreme youthfulness and a certain air of lonely dependence which marked [him]197-clyde ever since [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother and [Nicholson]418-nicholson had gone : " [I]197-clyde 'll always be in easy reach . "[197-clyde] And here [he]197-clyde turned as if to go .

But [Clyde]197-clyde , now taken by [him]197-clyde — [his]197-clyde vital , confident and kindly manner — so different to the tense , fearful and yet lonely life here , called after [him]197-clyde : " Oh , do n't go just yet . Please do n't . It 's very nice of [you]197-clyde to come and see [me]197-clyde and [I]197-clyde 'm obliged to [you]197-clyde . And certainly [any one in here]6266-any one in here pays a good deal . "[197-clyde] [His]197-clyde eyes looked very sad and strained .

And at once , [McMillan]431-mcmillan , now deeply touched for the first time replied : " [Clyde]197-clyde , [you]197-clyde need n't worry . ' [The Lord]3114-the lord will be a refuge for [the oppressed]6268-the oppressed ; a refuge in time of trouble . ' "[431-mcmillan]

[He]3755-he smiled as though [he]3755-he were now really fond of [Clyde]197-clyde . And [Clyde]197-clyde feeling this and being intrigued by it , replied that there was n't anything just then that [he]197-clyde wanted to say except to tell [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother that [he]197-clyde was all right — and make [her]688-his mother feel a little better about [him]197-clyde , maybe , if [he]197-clyde could . [Her]688-his mother letters were very sad , [he]197-clyde thought . [She]688-his mother worried too much about [him]197-clyde . Besides [he]197-clyde , [himself]197-clyde , was n't feeling so very good — not a little run down and worried these days . Who would n't be in [his]197-clyde position ? Indeed , if only [he]197-clyde could win to spiritual peace through prayer , [he]197-clyde would be glad to do it . [[His]197-clyde mother]688-his mother had always urged [him]197-clyde to pray — but up to now [he]197-clyde was sorry to say [he]197-clyde had n't followed [her]688-his mother advice very much . [He]197-clyde looked very distrait and gloomy — the marked prison pallor having long since settled on [his]197-clyde face .

And [the Reverend Duncan]438-the reverend mcmillan , now very much touched by [his]197-clyde state , replied : " Well , do n't worry , [Clyde]197-clyde . Enlightenment and peace are surely going to come to [you]197-clyde . [I]438-the reverend mcmillan can see that . [You]197-clyde have a Bible there , [I]438-the reverend mcmillan see . Open it anywhere in Psalms and read . The 51st , 91st , 23rd . Open to [St. John]436-st. john . Read it all — over and over . Think and pray — and think on all the things about [you]197-clyde — the moon , the stars , the sun , the trees , [the sea]6269-the sea — [your]197-clyde own beating heart , [your]197-clyde body and strength — and ask [yourself]197-clyde who made [them]6270-them . How did they come to be ? Then , if [you]197-clyde ca n't explain them , ask [yourself]197-clyde if the one who made [them]6270-them and [you]197-clyde — whoever [he]197-clyde is , whatever [he]197-clyde is , wherever [he]197-clyde is , is n't strong and wise enough and kind enough to help [you]197-clyde when [you]197-clyde need help — provide [you]197-clyde with light and peace and guidance , when [you]197-clyde need [them]6270-them . Just ask [yourself]197-clyde what of [the Maker of all this certain reality]6271-the maker of all this certain reality . And then ask [Him]6271-the maker of all this certain reality — [the Creator of it all]6272-the creator of it all — to tell [you]197-clyde how and what to do . Do n't doubt . Just ask and see . Ask in the night — in the day . Bow [your]197-clyde head and pray and see . Verily , [He]6271-the maker of all this certain reality will not fail [you]197-clyde . [I]438-the reverend mcmillan know because [I]438-the reverend mcmillan have that peace . "[438-the reverend mcmillan]

[He]3758-he stared at [Clyde]197-clyde convincingly — then smiled and departed . And [Clyde]197-clyde , leaning against [his]197-clyde cell door , began to wonder . [The Creator]3759-the creator ! [[His]197-clyde Creator]3760-his creator ! [The Creator of [the World!]167-the world!]3761-the creator of the world! ... Ask and see — !

And yet — there was still lingering here in [him]197-clyde that old contempt of [his]197-clyde for religion and its fruits,—the constant and yet fruitless prayers and exhortations of [[his]197-clyde father]1778-his father and [mother]2083-mother . Was [he]197-clyde going to turn to religion now , solely because [he]197-clyde was in difficulties and frightened like [these others]1155-these others ? [He]197-clyde hoped not . Not like that , anyway .

Just the same the mood , as well as the temperament of [the Reverend Duncan McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan — [his]438-the reverend mcmillan young , forceful , convinced and dramatic body , face , eyes , now intrigued and then moved [Clyde]197-clyde as [no religionist or minister]3765-no religionist or minister in all [his]197-clyde life before ever had . [He]197-clyde was interested , arrested and charmed by [the man]504-the man 's faith — whether at once or not at all — ever — [he]197-clyde could come to put the reliance in it that plainly [this man]749-this man did .

The personal conviction and force of such [an individual]3768-an individual as [the Reverend McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan , while in one sense an old story to [Clyde]197-clyde and not anything which so late as eighteen months before could have moved [him]197-clyde in any way ( since all [his]197-clyde life [he]197-clyde had been accustomed to something like it ) , still here , under these circumstances , affected [him]197-clyde differently . [Incarcerated]439-incarcerated , withdrawn from [the world]1694-the world , compelled by the highly circumscribed nature of [this death house]3568-this death house life to find solace or relief in [his]197-clyde own thoughts , [Clyde]197-clyde 's , like [every other temperament similarly limited]3771-every other temperament similarly limited , was compelled to devote itself either to the past , the present or the future . But the past was so painful to contemplate at any point . It seared and burned . And the present ( [his]197-clyde immediate surroundings ) as well as the future with its deadly fear of what was certain to happen in case [his]197-clyde appeal failed , were two phases equally frightful to [his]197-clyde waking consciousness .

What followed then was what invariably follows in the wake of every tortured consciousness . From what it dreads or hates , yet knows or feels to be unescapable , it takes refuge in that which may be hoped for — or at least imagined . But what was to be hoped for or imagined ? Because of the new suggestion offered by [Nicholson]418-nicholson , a new trial was all that [he]197-clyde had to look forward to , in which case , and assuming [himself]197-clyde to be acquitted thereafter , [he]197-clyde could go far , far away — to [Australia]168-australia — or [Africa]169-africa — or [Mexico]170-mexico — or [some such place as that]3772-some such place as that , where , under a different name — [his]197-clyde old connections and ambitions relating to that superior social life that had so recently intrigued [him]197-clyde , laid aside , [he]197-clyde might recover [himself]197-clyde in some small way . But directly in the path of that hopeful imagining , of course , stood [the death]3773-the death 's head figure of a refusal on the part of [the Court of Appeals]3233-the court of appeals to grant [him]197-clyde a new trial . Why not — after [that jury at [Bridgeburg]11-bridgeburg]3775-that jury at bridgeburg ? And then — as in that dream in which [he]197-clyde turned from the tangle of snakes to face the tramping rhinoceros with its two horns — [he]197-clyde was confronted by that awful thing in [the adjoining room]3776-the adjoining room — that chair ! That chair ! Its straps and its flashes which so regularly dimmed the lights in [this room]1131-this room . [He]197-clyde could not bear to think of [his]197-clyde entering [there]650-there — ever . And yet supposing [his]197-clyde appeal was refused ! Away ! [He]197-clyde would like to think no more about it .

But then , apart from that what was there to think of ? It was that very question that up to the time of the arrival of [the Rev. Duncan McMillan]431-mcmillan , with [his]431-mcmillan plea for a direct and certainly ( as [he]431-mcmillan insisted ) fruitful appeal to [the Creator of all things]3779-the creator of all things , that had been definitely torturing [Clyde]197-clyde . Yet see — how simple was [his]431-mcmillan solution !

" It was given unto [you]6273-you to know the Peace of [God]246-god , "[431-mcmillan] [he]431-mcmillan insisted , quoting [Paul]440-paul and thereafter sentences from [Corinthians]171-corinthians , [Galatians]3780-galatians , [Ephesians]441-ephesians , on how easy it was — if [Clyde]197-clyde would but repeat and pray as [he]431-mcmillan had asked [him]197-clyde to — for [him]197-clyde to know and delight in the " peace that passeth all understanding . "[431-mcmillan] It was with [him]197-clyde , all around [him]197-clyde . [He]197-clyde had but to seek ; confess the miseries and errors of [his]197-clyde heart , and express contrition . " Ask , and [ye]6273-you shall receive ; seek , and [ye]6273-you shall find ; knock , and it shall be opened unto [you]6273-you . For [every one that asketh , receiveth]6274-every one that asketh , receiveth ; and [he]6274-every one that asketh , receiveth that seeketh , findeth ; and to [him]6274-every one that asketh , receiveth that knocketh it shall be opened . For what man is there of [you]6273-you whom , if [[his]1778-his father son]1713-his son ask bread , will give [him]1778-his father a stone ; or , if [he]1778-his father ask fish , will give [him]1778-his father a serpent ? "[197-clyde] So [he]197-clyde quoted , beautifully and earnestly .

And yet before [Clyde]197-clyde always was the example of [[his]197-clyde father]1778-his father and [mother]2083-mother . What had [they]3783-they ? It had not availed [them]3783-they much — praying . Neither , as [he]197-clyde noticed here , did it appear to avail or aid [these other condemned men , the majority of whom lent [themselves]3784-these other condemned men , the majority of whom lent themselves to the pleas or prayers of either priest or rabbi or minister to the pleas or prayers of either [priest]3785-priest or [rabbi]3786-rabbi or [minister]2171-minister]3784-these other condemned men , the majority of whom lent themselves to the pleas or prayers of either priest or rabbi or minister , [one and the other of whom was about daily]3788-one and the other of whom was about daily . Yet were [they]3783-they not led to [their]3783-they death just the same — and complaining or protesting , or mad like [Cutrone]421-pasquale , or indifferent ? As for [himself]197-clyde , up to this [he]197-clyde had not been interested by any of these . [Bunk]442-bunk . [Notions]443-notions . Of what ? [He]197-clyde could not say . Nevertheless , here was the appealing [Rev. Duncan McMillan]431-mcmillan . [His]431-mcmillan mild , serene eyes . [His]431-mcmillan sweet voice . [His]431-mcmillan faith . It moved and intrigued [Clyde]197-clyde deeply . Could there — could there ? [He]197-clyde was so lonely — so despairing — so very much in need of help .

Was it not also true ( the teaching of [the Rev. McMillan]431-mcmillan — influencing [him]197-clyde to that extent at least ) that if [he]197-clyde had led a better life — had paid more attention to what [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother had said and taught — not gone into [that house of prostitution in [Kansas City]45-kansas city]3790-that house of prostitution in kansas city — or pursued [Hortense Briggs]444-hortense briggs in the evil way that [he]197-clyde had — or after [her]3791-her , [Roberta]195-roberta — had been content to work and save , as no doubt [most men]3792-most men were — would [he]197-clyde not be better off than [he]197-clyde now was ? But then again , there was the fact or truth of those very strong impulses and desires within [himself]197-clyde that were so very , very hard to overcome . [He]197-clyde had thought of those , too , and then of the fact that [many other people like [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother , [[his]197-clyde uncle]821-his uncle , [[his]197-clyde cousin]2741-his cousin]3793-many other people like his mother , his uncle , his cousin , and [this minister here]3797-this minister here , did not seem to be troubled by [them]3793-many other people like his mother , his uncle , his cousin . And yet also [he]197-clyde was given to imagining at times that perhaps it was because of superior mental and moral courage in the face of passions and desires , equivalent to [his]197-clyde own , which led [these others]1155-these others to do so much better . [He]197-clyde was perhaps just willfully devoting [himself]197-clyde to these other thoughts and ways , as [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother and [McMillan]431-mcmillan and [most every one else whom [he]197-clyde had heard talk since [his]197-clyde arrest]3800-most every one else whom he had heard talk since his arrest seemed to think .

What did it all mean ? Was there [a God]4286-a god ? Did [He]197-clyde interfere in the affairs of [men]2208-men as [Mr. McMillan]445-mcmillan was now contending ? Was it possible that [one]955-one could turn to [Him]197-clyde , or at least some creative power , in some such hour as this and when [one]955-one had always ignored [Him]197-clyde before , and ask for aid ? Decidedly one needed aid under such circumstances — so alone and ordered and controlled by law — not [man]585-man — since these , [all of [them]3806-all of them]3806-all of them , were [the veriest servants of the law]3807-the veriest servants of the law . But would this mysterious power be likely to grant aid ? Did it really exist and hear the prayers of [men]2208-men ? [The Rev. McMillan]431-mcmillan insisted yes . " [He]197-clyde hath said [God]246-god hath forgotten ; [He]197-clyde hideth [His]197-clyde face . But [He]197-clyde has not forgotten . [He]197-clyde has not hidden [His]197-clyde face . "[431-mcmillan] But was that true ? Was there anything to it ? Tortured by the need of some mental if not material support in the face of [his]197-clyde great danger , [Clyde]197-clyde was now doing what [every other human in related circumstances]3809-every other human in related circumstances invariably does — seeking , and yet in the most indirect and involute and all but unconscious way , the presence or existence at least of some superhuman or supernatural personality or power that could and would aid [him]197-clyde in some way — beginning to veer — however slightly or unconsciously as yet,—toward the personalization and humanization of forces , of which , except in the guise of religion , [he]197-clyde had not the faintest conception . " [The Heavens]446-the heavens declare the Glory of [God]246-god , and the Firmament sheweth [His]246-god handiwork . "[197-clyde] [He]197-clyde recalled that as a placard in one of [[his]197-clyde mother]688-his mother 's mission windows . And another which read : " For [He]246-god is [Thy]246-god life and [Thy]246-god length of Days . "[197-clyde] Just the same — and far from it as yet , even in the face of [his]197-clyde sudden predisposition toward [the Rev. Duncan McMillan]431-mcmillan , was [he]197-clyde seriously moved to assume that in religion of any kind was [he]197-clyde likely to find surcease from [his]197-clyde present miseries ?

And yet the weeks and months going by — [the Rev. McMillan]431-mcmillan calling regularly thereafter , every two weeks at the longest , sometimes every week and inquiring after [his]197-clyde state , listening to [his]197-clyde wants , advising [him]197-clyde as to [his]197-clyde health and peace of mind . And [Clyde]197-clyde , anxious to retain [his]197-clyde interest and visits , gradually , more and more , yielding [himself]197-clyde to [his]197-clyde friendship and influence . That high spirituality . That beautiful voice . And quoting always such soothing things . " [Brethren]447-brethren now are [we]447-brethren [the children of [God]246-god]6276-the children of god . And it doth not yet appear what [we]447-brethren shall be ; but [we]447-brethren know that when [He]246-god shall appear [we]447-brethren shall be like [Him]246-god , for [we]447-brethren shall see [Him]246-god as [He]246-god is . And [every man that has this hope in [him]246-god]6277-every man that has this hope in him purifieth [himself]246-god even as [He]246-god is pure . "[197-clyde]

" Hereby know that [we]447-brethren dwell in [Him]246-god and [He]246-god in [us]447-brethren , because [He]246-god hath given [us]447-brethren of [His]246-god spirit . "[197-clyde]

" For [ye]6278-ye are bought with a price . "[197-clyde]

" Of [His]246-god own will begot [He]246-god [us]447-brethren with the word of truth , and [we]447-brethren should be a kind of first fruits of [[His]246-god creatures]6279-his creatures . And every good and every perfect gift is from above and cometh down from [the Father of lights , with whom is no variableness , neither shadow of turning]6280-the father of lights , with whom is no variableness , neither shadow of turning . "[197-clyde]

" Draw nigh unto [God]246-god and [He]246-god will draw nigh unto [you]6278-ye . "[197-clyde]

[He]3811-he was inclined , at times , to feel that there might be peace and strength — aid , even — who could say , in appealing to this power . It was the force and the earnestness of [the Rev. McMillan]431-mcmillan operating upon [him]3811-he .

And yet , the question of repentance — and with it confession . But to whom ? [The Rev. Duncan McMillan]431-mcmillan , of course . [He]3811-he seemed to feel that it was necessary for [Clyde]197-clyde to purge [his]3811-he soul to [him]3811-he — or [some one like [him]3811-he]3812-some one like him — [a material and yet spiritual emissary of [God]246-god]3813-a material and yet spiritual emissary of god . But just there was the trouble . For there was all of that false testimony [he]3811-he had given in the trial , yet on which had been based [his]3811-he appeal . To go back on that now , and when [his]3811-he appeal was pending . Better wait , had [he]3811-he not , until [he]3811-he saw how that appeal had eventuated .

But , ah , how shabby , false , fleeting , insincere . To imagine that [any God]3814-any god would bother with [a person who sought to dicker in such a way]3815-a person who sought to dicker in such a way . No , no . That was not right either . What would [the Rev. McMillan]3816-the rev. mcmillan think of [him]3811-he if [he]3811-he knew what [he]3811-he was thinking ?

But again there was the troubling question in [his]3811-he own mind as to [his]3811-he real guilt — the amount of it . True there was no doubt that [he]3811-he had plotted to kill [Roberta]195-roberta [there]650-there at first — a most dreadful thing as [he]3811-he now saw it . For the complications and the fever in connection with [his]3811-he desire for [Sondra]238-sondra having subsided somewhat , it was possible on occasion now for [him]3811-he to reason without the desperate sting and tang of the mental state that had characterized [him]3811-he at the time when [he]3811-he was so immediately in touch with [her]195-roberta . Those terrible , troubled days when in spite of [himself]3811-he — as [he]3811-he now understood it ( [Belknap]324-belknap 's argument having cleared it up for [him]3811-he ) [he]3811-he had burned with that wild fever which was not unakin in its manifestations to a form of insanity . The beautiful [Sondra]238-sondra ! [The glorious Sondra]238-sondra ! The witchery and fire of [her]238-sondra smile then ! Even now that dreadful fever was not entirely out but only smoldering — smothered by all of the dreadful things that had since happened to [him]3811-he .

Also , it must be said on [his]3811-he behalf now , must it not — that never , under any other circumstances , would [he]3811-he have succumbed to any such terrible thought or plot as that — to kill [any one]4181-any one — let alone [a girl like [Roberta]195-roberta]820-a girl like roberta — unless [he]3811-he had been so infatuated — lunatic , even . But had not [the jury there at [Bridgeburg]11-bridgeburg]3820-the jury there at bridgeburg listened to that plea with contempt ? And would [the Court of Appeals]3233-the court of appeals think differently ? [He]3811-he feared not . And yet was it not true ? Or was [he]3811-he all wrong ? Or what ? Could [the Rev. McMillan]431-mcmillan or [any one else to whom [he]3811-he would explain tell [him]3811-he as to that]3822-any one else to whom he would explain tell him as to that ? [He]3811-he would like to talk to [him]3811-he about it — confess everything perhaps , in order to get [himself]3811-he clear on all this . Further , there was the fact that having plotted for [Sondra]238-sondra 's sake ( and [God]246-god , if [no one else]4859-no one else , knew that ) [he]3811-he still had not been able to execute it . And that had not been brought out in the trial , because the false form of defense used permitted no explanation of the real truth then — and yet it was a mitigating circumstance , was it not — or would [the Rev. McMillan]3816-the rev. mcmillan think so ? A lie had to be used , as [Jephson]320-jephson saw it . But did that make it any the less true ?

There were phases of this thing , the tangles and doubts involved in that dark , savage plot of [his]3811-he , as [he]3811-he now saw and brooded on it , which were not so easily to be disposed of . Perhaps the two worst were , first , that in bringing [Roberta]195-roberta [there]650-there to that point on [that lake]4165-that lake — [that lone spot]3827-that lone spot — and then growing so weak and furious with [himself]3811-he because of [his]3811-he own incapacity to do evil , [he]3811-he had frightened [her]195-roberta into rising and trying to come to [him]3811-he . And that in the first instance made it possible for [her]195-roberta to be thus accidentally struck by [him]3811-he and so made [him]3811-he , in part at least , guilty of that blow — or did it?—a murderous , sinful blow in that sense . Maybe . What would [the Rev. McMillan]431-mcmillan say to that ? And since because of that [she]195-roberta had fallen into [the water]1009-the water , was [he]3811-he not guilty of [her]195-roberta falling ? It was a thought that troubled [him]3811-he very much now — [his]3811-he constructive share of guilt in all that . Regardless of what [Oberwaltzer]326-justice oberwaltzer had said there at the trial in regard to [his]3811-he swimming away from [her]195-roberta — that if [she]195-roberta had accidentally fallen in [the water]1009-the water , it was no crime on [his]3811-he part , supposing [he]3811-he refused to rescue her,—still , as [he]3811-he now saw it , and especially when taken in connection with all that [he]3811-he had thought in regard to [Roberta]195-roberta up to that moment , it was a crime just the same , was it not ? Would n't [God]246-god — [McMillan]431-mcmillan — think so ? And unquestionably , as [Mason]185-mason had so shrewdly pointed out at the trial , [he]3811-he might have saved [her]195-roberta . And would have too , no doubt , if [she]195-roberta had been [Sondra]238-sondra — or even [the Roberta of the summer before]3830-the roberta of the summer before . Besides , the fear of [her]195-roberta dragging [him]3811-he down had been no decent fear . ( It was at nights in [his]3811-he bunk at this time that [he]3811-he argued and reasoned with [himself]3811-he , seeing that [McMillan]431-mcmillan was urging [him]3811-he now to repent and make peace with [[his]3811-he God]3831-his god . ) Yes , [he]3811-he would have to admit that to [himself]3811-he . Decidedly and instantly [he]3811-he would have sought to save [her]195-roberta life , if it had been [Sondra]238-sondra . And such being the case , [he]3811-he would have to confess that — if [he]3811-he confessed at all to [the Rev. McMillan]431-mcmillan — or to whomever else [one]955-one told the truth — when [one]955-one did tell it — [the public at large]3834-the public at large perhaps . But such a confession once made , would it not surely and truly lead to [his]3811-he conviction ? And did [he]3811-he want to convict [himself]3811-he now and so die ?

No , no , better wait a while perhaps — at least until [the Court of Appeals]3233-the court of appeals had passed on [his]3811-he case . Why jeopardize [his]3811-he case when [God]246-god already knew what the truth was ? Truly , truly [he]3811-he was sorry . [He]3811-he could see how terrible all this was now — how much misery and heartache , apart from the death of [Roberta]195-roberta , [he]3811-he had caused . But still — still — was not life sweet ? Oh , if [he]3811-he could only get out ! Oh , if [he]3811-he could only go away from here — never to see or hear or feel anything more of this terrible terror that now hung over [him]3811-he . The slow coming dark — the slow coming dawn . The long night ! The sighs — the groans . The tortures by day and by night until it seemed at times as though [he]3811-he should go mad ; and would perhaps except for [McMillan]431-mcmillan , who now appeared devoted to [him]3811-he — so kind , appealing and reassuring , too , at times . [He]3811-he would just like to sit down some day — here or somewhere — and tell [him]431-mcmillan all and get [him]431-mcmillan to say how really guilty , if at all , [he]3811-he thought [him]431-mcmillan to be — and if so guilty to get [him]431-mcmillan to pray for [him]431-mcmillan . At times [he]3811-he felt so sure that [[his]3811-he mother]688-his mother 's and [the Rev. Duncan McMillan]431-mcmillan 's prayers would do [him]3811-he so much more good with [this God]3837-this god than any prayers of [his]3811-he own would . Somehow [he]3811-he could n't pray yet . And at times hearing [McMillan]431-mcmillan pray , softly and melodiously , [his]431-mcmillan voice entering through the bars — or , reading from [Galatians]448-galatians , [Thessalonians]172-thessalonians , [Corinthians]171-corinthians , [he]3811-he felt as though [he]3811-he must tell [him]431-mcmillan everything , and soon .

But the days going by until finally one day six weeks after — and when because of [his]3811-he silence in regard to [himself]3811-he , [the Rev. Duncan]431-mcmillan was beginning to despair of ever affecting [him]3811-he in any way toward [his]3811-he proper contrition and salvation — a letter or note from [Sondra]238-sondra . It came through [[the warden]3282-the warden 's office]3283-the warden 's office and by the hand of [the Rev. Preston Guilford]450-the rev. preston guilford , [the Protestant chaplain of [the prison]3012-the prison]3840-the protestant chaplain of the prison , but was not signed . It was , however , on good paper , and because the rule of [the prison]3012-the prison so requiring had been opened and read . Nevertheless , on account of the nature of the contents which seemed to both [the warden]3282-the warden and [the Rev. Guilford]450-the rev. preston guilford to be more charitable and punitive than otherwise , and because plainly , if not verifiably , it was from that Miss X of repute or notoriety in connection with [his]3811-he trial , it was decided , after due deliberation , that [Clyde]197-clyde should be permitted to read it — even that it was best that [he]197-clyde should . Perhaps it would prove of value as a lesson . The way of [the transgressor]3844-the transgressor . And so it was handed to [him]197-clyde at the close of a late fall day — after a long and dreary summer had passed ( soon a year since [he]197-clyde had entered [here]4244-here ) . And [he]197-clyde taking it . And although it was typewritten with no date nor place on the envelope , which was postmarked [New York]63-new york — yet sensing somehow that it might be from [her]238-sondra . And growing decidedly nervous — so much so that [his]197-clyde hand trembled slightly . And then reading — over and over and over — during many days thereafter : " [Clyde]197-clyde — This is so that [you]197-clyde will not think that [some one once dear to [you]197-clyde]6281-some one once dear to you has utterly forgotten [you]197-clyde . [She]238-sondra has suffered much , too . And though [she]238-sondra can never understand how [you]197-clyde could have done as [you]197-clyde did , still , even now , although [she]238-sondra is never to see [you]197-clyde again , [she]238-sondra is not without sorrow and sympathy and wishes [you]197-clyde freedom and happiness . "[197-clyde]

But no signature — no trace of [her]238-sondra own handwriting . [She]238-sondra was afraid to sign [her]238-sondra name and [she]238-sondra was too remote from [him]197-clyde in [her]238-sondra mood now to let [him]197-clyde know where [she]238-sondra was . [New York]63-new york ! But it might have been sent there from anywhere to mail . And [she]238-sondra would not let [him]197-clyde know — would never let [him]197-clyde know — even though [he]197-clyde died here later , as well [he]197-clyde might . [His]197-clyde last hope — the last trace of [his]197-clyde dream vanished . Forever ! It was at that moment , as when night at last falls upon the faintest remaining gleam of dusk in [the west]788-the west . A dim , weakening tinge of pink — and then the dark .

[He]197-clyde seated [himself]197-clyde on [his]197-clyde cot . The wretched stripes of [his]197-clyde uniform and [his]197-clyde gray felt shoes took [his]197-clyde eye . [A felon]3847-a felon . These stripes . These shoes . [This cell]6257-this cell . This uncertain , threatening prospect so very terrible to contemplate at any time . And then this letter . So this was the end of all that wonderful dream ! And for this [he]197-clyde had sought so desperately to disengage [himself]197-clyde from [Roberta]195-roberta — even to the point of deciding to slay [her]195-roberta . This ! This ! [He]197-clyde toyed with the letter , then held it quite still . Where was [she]195-roberta now ? Who in love with , maybe ? [She]195-roberta had had time to change perhaps . [She]195-roberta had only been captivated by [him]197-clyde a little , maybe . And then that terrible revelation in connection with [him]197-clyde had destroyed forever , no doubt , all sentiment in connection with [him]197-clyde . [She]195-roberta was free . [She]195-roberta had beauty — wealth . Now some other —

[He]197-clyde got up and walked to [[his]197-clyde cell]1588-his cell door to still a great pain . Over the way , in [that cell [the Chinaman]3622-the chinaman had once occupied]3850-that cell the chinaman had once occupied , was a Negro — [Wash Higgins]451-wash higgins . [He]451-wash higgins had stabbed [a waiter]3852-a waiter in [a restaurant]3853-a restaurant , so it was said , who had refused [him]451-wash higgins food and then insulted [him]451-wash higgins . And next to [him]451-wash higgins was [a young Jew]3854-a young jew . [He]451-wash higgins had killed [the proprietor of [a jewelry store]3856-a jewelry store]3855-the proprietor of a jewelry store in trying to rob [it]3856-a jewelry store . But [he]197-clyde was very broken and collapsed now that [he]197-clyde was here to die — sitting for the most part all day on [his]197-clyde cot , [his]197-clyde head in [his]197-clyde hands . [Clyde]197-clyde could see both now from where [he]197-clyde stood — [the Jew]3857-the jew holding [his]197-clyde head . But [the Negro]3858-the negro on [his]3858-the negro cot , one leg above the other , smoking — and singing —

" Oh , [big wheel ro - a - lin']6282-big wheel ro - a - lin' ... hmp ! Oh , [big wheel ro - a - lin' ... hmp]6283-big wheel ro - a - lin' ... hmp ! "[3858-the negro] And then [Clyde]197-clyde , unable to get away from [his]197-clyde own thoughts , turning again .

[Condemned to die]3859-condemned to die ! [He]197-clyde . And this was the end as to [Sondra]238-sondra . [He]197-clyde could feel it . [Farewell]452-farewell . " Although [she]238-sondra is never to see [you]197-clyde again . "[452-farewell] [He]197-clyde threw [himself]197-clyde on [his]197-clyde couch — not to weep but to rest — [he]197-clyde felt so weary . [Lycurgus]33-lycurgus . [Fourth Lake]85-fourth lake . [Bear Lake]50-bear lake . Laughter — kisses — smiles . What was to have been in the fall of the preceding year . And now — a year later .

But [then,—that young Jew]3860-then,—that young jew . There was some religious chant into which [he]197-clyde fell when [his]197-clyde mental tortures would no longer endure silence . And oh , how sad . [Many of [the prisoners]3386-the prisoners]3861-many of the prisoners had cried out against it . And yet , oh , how appropriate now , somehow .

" [I]453-big tom rooney have been evil . [I]453-big tom rooney have been unkind . [I]453-big tom rooney have lied . Oh ! Oh ! Oh ! [I]453-big tom rooney have been unfaithful . When [the guard]3422-the guard , an hour later , placed [his]3422-the guard supper on the shelf in the door , [he]3422-the guard made no move . Food ! And when [the guard]3422-the guard returned in another thirty minutes , there it was , still untouched , as was [the Jew's]455-the jew's — and was taken away in silence . [Guards]3868-guards knew when blue devils had seized [the inmates of [these cages]3870-these cages]3869-the inmates of these cages . [They]3868-guards could n't eat . And there were times , too , when [even guards]3871-even guards could n't eat .

The depression resulting even after two days was apparent to [the Reverend McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan , who was concerned to know why . More recently , [he]438-the reverend mcmillan had been led to believe by [Clyde]197-clyde 's manner , [his]438-the reverend mcmillan visits , if not the fact that the totality of [his]438-the reverend mcmillan preachments , had not been greeted with as much warmth as [he]438-the reverend mcmillan would have liked , that by degrees [Clyde]197-clyde was being won to [his]197-clyde own spiritual viewpoint . With no little success , as it had seemed to [him]438-the reverend mcmillan , [he]438-the reverend mcmillan had counseled [Clyde]197-clyde as to the folly of depression and despair . " What ! Was not the peace of [God]246-god within [his]438-the reverend mcmillan grasp and for the asking . To one who sought [God]246-god and found [Him]246-god , as [he]438-the reverend mcmillan surely would , if [he]438-the reverend mcmillan sought , there could be no sorrow , but only joy . ' Hereby know [we]6287-we that [we]6287-we dwell in [Him]246-god , and [He]246-god in [us]6287-we , because [He]246-god hath given [us]6287-we of [His]246-god spirit . ' "[438-the reverend mcmillan] So [he]197-clyde preached or read,—until finally — two weeks after receiving the letter from [Sondra]238-sondra and because of the deep depression into which [he]197-clyde had sunk on account of it , [Clyde]197-clyde was finally moved to request of [him]197-clyde that [he]197-clyde try to induce [the warden]3282-the warden to allow [him]197-clyde to be taken to [some other cell or room apart from [this room]1131-this room or cell]3873-some other cell or room apart from this room or cell which seemed to [Clyde]197-clyde to be filled with too many of [his]197-clyde tortured thoughts , in order that [he]197-clyde might talk with [him]3282-the warden and get [his]3282-the warden advice . As [he]197-clyde told [the Reverend McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan , [he]197-clyde did not appear to be able to solve [his]197-clyde true responsibility in connection with all that had so recently occurred in [his]197-clyde life , and because of which [he]197-clyde seemed not to be able to find that peace of mind of which [McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan talked so much . Perhaps ... ,—there must be something wrong with [his]197-clyde viewpoint . Actually [he]197-clyde would like to go over the offense of which [he]197-clyde was convicted and see if there was anything wrong in [his]197-clyde understanding of it . [He]197-clyde was not so sure now . And [McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan , greatly stirred,—an enormous spiritual triumph , this — as [he]438-the reverend mcmillan saw it — the true reward of faith and prayer , at once proceeding to [the warden]3282-the warden , who was glad enough to be of service in such a cause . And [he]438-the reverend mcmillan permitted the use of [one of [the cells in [the old death house]3353-the old death house]3877-the cells in the old death house]3876-one of the cells in the old death house for as long as [he]438-the reverend mcmillan should require , and with no guard between [himself]438-the reverend mcmillan and [Clyde]197-clyde — one only remaining in [the general hall]3879-the general hall outside .

And there [Clyde]197-clyde began the story of [his]197-clyde relations with [Roberta]195-roberta and [Sondra]238-sondra . Yet because of all that had been set forth at the trial , merely referring to most of the evidence — apart from [his]197-clyde defense — the change of heart , as so ; afterwards dwelling more particularly on the fatal adventure with [Roberta]195-roberta in [the boat]4231-the boat . Did [the Reverend McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan — because of the original plotting — and hence the original intent — think [him]197-clyde guilty?—especially in view of [his]197-clyde obsession over [Sondra]238-sondra — all [his]197-clyde dreams in regard to [her]238-sondra — did that truly constitute murder ? [He]197-clyde was asking this because , as [he]197-clyde said , it was as [he]197-clyde had done — not as [his]197-clyde testimony at the trial had indicated that [he]197-clyde had done . It was a lie that [he]197-clyde had experienced a change of heart . [[His]197-clyde attorneys]2189-his attorneys had counseled that defense as best , since [they]2189-his attorneys did not feel that [he]197-clyde was guilty , and had thought that plan the quickest route to liberty . But it was a lie . In connection with [his]197-clyde mental state also there in [the boat]4231-the boat , before and after [her]195-roberta rising and attempting to come to [him,—and]3883-him,—and that blow , and [after,—he]3884-after,—he had not told the truth either — quite . That unintentional blow , as [he]197-clyde now wished to explain , since it affected [his]197-clyde efforts at religious meditation,—a desire to present [himself]197-clyde honestly to [[his]197-clyde Creator]3760-his creator , if at all ( [he]197-clyde did not then explain that as yet [he]197-clyde had scarcely attempted to so present [himself)—there]3886-himself)—there was more to it than [he]197-clyde had been able yet to make clear , even to [himself]197-clyde . In fact even now to [himself]197-clyde there was much that was evasive and even insoluble about it . [He]197-clyde had said that there had been no anger — that there had been a change of heart . But there had been no change of heart . In fact , just before [she]195-roberta had risen to come to [him]197-clyde , there had been a complex troubled state , bordering , as [he]197-clyde now saw it , almost upon trance or palsy , and due — but [he]197-clyde could scarcely say to what it was due , exactly . [He]197-clyde had thought at first — or afterwards — that it was partly due to pity for [Roberta]195-roberta — or , at least the shame of so much cruelty in connection with [her]195-roberta — [his]197-clyde plan to strike [her]195-roberta . At the same time there was anger , too,—hate maybe — because of [her]195-roberta determination to force [him]197-clyde to do what [he]197-clyde did not wish to do . Thirdly — yet [he]197-clyde was not so sure as to that—(he had thought about it so long and yet [he]197-clyde was not sure even now)—there might have been fear as to the consequences of such an evil deed — although , just at that time , as it seemed to [him]197-clyde now , [he]197-clyde was not thinking of the consequences — or of anything save [his]197-clyde inability to do as [he]197-clyde had come to do — and feeling angry as to that .

Yet in the blow — the accidental blow that had followed upon [her]195-roberta rising and attempting to come to [him]197-clyde , had been some anger against [her]195-roberta for wanting to come near [him]197-clyde at all . And that it was perhaps — [he]197-clyde was truly not sure , even now , that had given that blow its so destructive force . It was so afterward , anyhow , that [he]197-clyde was compelled to think of it . And yet there was also the truth that in rising [he]197-clyde was seeking to save [her]195-roberta — even in spite of [his]197-clyde hate . That [he]197-clyde was also , for the moment at least , sorry for that blow . Again , though , once [the boat]4231-the boat had upset and [both]2747-both were in the water — in all that confusion , and when [she]195-roberta was drowning , [he]197-clyde had been moved by the thought : " Do nothing . "[197-clyde] For thus [he]197-clyde would be rid of [her]195-roberta . Yes , [he]197-clyde had so thought . But again , there was the fact that all through , as [Mr. Belknap]323-belknap and [Mr. Jephson]320-jephson had pointed out , [he]197-clyde had been swayed by [his]197-clyde obsession for [Miss X]354-miss x , [the super motivating force in connection with all of this]3889-the super motivating force in connection with all of this . But now , did [the Reverend McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan , considering all that went before and all that came after — the fact that the unintentional blow still had had anger in it — angry dissatisfaction with [her]195-roberta — really — and that afterwards [he]197-clyde had not gone to [her]195-roberta rescue — as now — honestly and truly as [he]197-clyde was trying to show — did [he]197-clyde think that that constituted murder — mortal blood guilt for which spiritually , as well as legally , [he]197-clyde might be said to deserve death ? Did [he]197-clyde ? [He]197-clyde would like to know for [his]197-clyde own soul 's peace — so that [he]197-clyde could pray , maybe .

[The Reverend McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan hearing all this — and never in [his]197-clyde life before having heard or having had passed to [him]197-clyde so intricate and elusive and strange a problem — and because of [Clyde]197-clyde 's faith in and regard for [him]197-clyde , enormously impressed . And now sitting before [him]197-clyde quite still and pondering most deeply , sadly and even nervously — so serious and important was this request for an opinion — something which , as [he]197-clyde knew , [Clyde]197-clyde was counting on to give [him]197-clyde earthly and spiritual peace . But , none - the - less , [the Reverend McMillan]438-the reverend mcmillan was [himself]197-clyde too puzzled to answer so quickly .
